data.title: Rubens, Van Dyck and the Splendour of Flemish Painting. Exhibition catalogue, Museum of Fine Arts, Budapest
data.meta_description: Rubens, Van Dyck and the Splendour of Flemish Painting. Exhibition catalogue, Museum of Fine Arts, Budapest
data.text:
"Quart. Quarterly of Art History Institute at the University of Wroclaw" - call for papers Issue 56 (June 2020), 57 (September 2020), 58 (December 2020), and 59 (March 2021) Issue 56: Travelling and Art in Europe in the 17th and 18th Centuries The deadline for submission of papers: 1 March 2020 The issue will be published in the 2nd half of June 2020 Special editor of the issue: Prof. Dr. hab. Andrzej Kozieł Issue 57: Empty Spaces, Gaps and Omissions in Medieval Art The deadline for submission of papers: 5 June 2020 The issue will be published in the 2nd half of September 2020 Special editor of the issue: Dr. Agnieszka Patała Issue 58: Special Issue Dedicated to the Memory of Dr Andrzej Jarosz The deadline for submission of papers: 2 September 2020 The issue will be published in the 2nd half of December 2020 Special editors of the issue: Dr. hab. Justyna Bajda, Professor at Institute of Polish Philology University of Wroclaw and Prof. Dr. hab. Waldemar Okoń Issue 59: The Work of Deflation: Unlearning, Deskilling, Epistemologies of Ignorance The deadline for submission of papers: 2 December 2020 The issue will be published in the 2nd half of March 2021 Special editors of the issue: Prof. Dr. hab. Anna Markowska

The most important goal of the congress is to determine the current state of the discipline: where does art history stand in the year 2022, not only in Switzerland but also internationally? And what are its perspectives for the future? To this end, we have put together a threeday program consisting of a total of eleven sessions and two round table discussions. With over 100 speakers and session leaders, the congress reflects the breadth and diversity of art historical approaches and interests. Two topics will be our particular focus in 2022: the first of these is the Junior Researchers’ Forum, where doctoral students will have the chance to present their research in the new format of a “science slam”. A second focus is the guest country Japan, for which a dedicated session has been organized. We are delighted that this congress will take place in Zurich, a city distinguished by its many and diverse art institutions. https://www.vkks.ch/de/aktivitaeten/kongresse

pp. 128–29, 133: Leonardo da Vinci in the City Hall of Florence: Art and Politics; pp. 134–35, 139: Printing in Light and Dark: Chiaroscuro Woodcuts; pp. 148–49: Dürer and Raimondi: Chronicle of a Fictive Lawsuit; pp. 156–57: Artworks for Everyday Use: The Ephemeral Art of the Renaissance; pp. 166–67, 169: Raphael: Art in Collaboration; 186–87: Schema and Correction: Creative Copies in the Renaissance; 194–95, 201: Depicting the Human Body: In the Shadow of Michelangelo; pp. 202–3: Mythology Reloaded: Profane Love in Renaissance Art; pp. 230–31: At the Service of the Church: The Birth of the Italian Baroque
